instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2338: What is A2338? A2338 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2020 M1, Mid 2022 M2 with EMC 8162, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02020, 820-02773..

threads.title: (Solved )<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at apple logo
threads.message:
Hello ! Im new here and glad to be here ! Ive here a Macbook M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ! The problem is that he stuck at Apple logo then vome progress bar load 10 15 % and restart ! The board have no water damage and no corrosion ! Its look like new !
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is 11.99 Volt and fluctuate every 25 sec to 12.28 Volt ! diode mode 0.496 !
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL> is 3.8 Volt 0.150
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL> is 5.1 Volt 0.303 !
Can you help me ? Thank you very much !

threads.title: (Solved )<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at apple logo
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

You should try DFU revive.
If no data to save, go for restore directly.

threads.title: (Solved )<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at apple logo
threads.message:
Hi 2Informaticos ! Thank you very much !
I already try dfu mode but dont work !i have the black screen when the MB goes in DFU but AC 2 from Host didnt see the MB !  Wenn i try safe mode too it restart too !
I read that we can force DFU with some jump or something like that ! Will try with <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> with 1.8 v !

threads.title: (Solved )<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at apple logo
threads.message:
So i inject 1.8 v in <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> then i get 
The signal <SIGNAL>SOC_DFU_STATUT</SIGNAL> high with 1.2 V !
But is not recognized im Host MB â€¦

threads.title: (Solved )<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at apple logo
threads.message:
Did you follow all the steps in DFU tutorial?
Be sure to use the proper port and try another cable too.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)[/URL]

threads.title: (Solved )<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at apple logo
threads.message: I follow exactly this ! But why i get only 1.2 V on <SIGNAL>SOC_DFU_STATUS</SIGNAL> ? It schould be 1.8 V ! That why i think isnt detected with the Host MB !

threads.title: (Solved )<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at apple logo
threads.message:
I just saw that you've injected 1.8V into <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL>.
How and why???

Solder RV005 and use SV004/5 pads.

Why do you expect 1.8V there, if this is M1 machine (not T2)?
Pay more atention looking at schematics.
M1 uses 1V25 line for this purpose!

threads.title: (Solved )<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at apple logo
threads.message: Hi Informaticos ! Sorry i thoug i have to inject 1.8 V ! Sorry ! Just want to say its worked with dfu mode ! Many thanks informaticos !
